qas.question: What are two examples of scripts without orthographic rules?

context: Many scripts, including <b9_0>Arabic and Devanagari<b9_0/>, have special orthographic rules that require certain combinations of letterforms to be combined into special ligature forms. The rules governing ligature formation can be quite complex, requiring special script-shaping technologies such as ACE (<a0_0><b6_0>Arabic Calligraphic Engine<b6_0/><a0_0/> by <a1_0>DecoType<a1_0/> in the <a2_0><b5_0>1980s<b5_0/><a2_0/> and used to generate all the Arabic examples in the printed editions of the Unicode Standard), which became the proof of concept for OpenType (by <a3_0><b8_0>Adobe and Microsoft<b8_0/><a3_0/>), Graphite (by <a4_0>SIL International<a4_0/>), or AAT (by <b7_0>Apple<b7_0/>).
